system.title: steam engine
system.description: a machine using heat and the steam of from water to generate energy
system.goals: identify a fault cause graph for steam engines

faults_and_causes.title: Leaks
faults_and_causes.description: Steam or water leaking from the engine can indicate faulty seals or gaskets, worn or damaged piston rings, or cracks in the cylinder or boiler.

causes.title: Faulty seals or gaskets
causes.description: Cracks in the cylinder or boiler

causes.title: Worn or damaged piston rings
causes.description: Incorrect installation or alignment

causes.title: Poor maintenance
causes.description: Overheating

causes.title: Incorrect operating pressure
causes.description: Foreign objects in the cylinder

causes.title: Worn-out piston rods
causes.description: Incorrect lubrication

faults_and_causes.title: Overheating
faults_and_causes.description: Excessive heat can cause damage to the engine's components, including the cylinder, piston, and valves. This can be caused by a variety of factors, such as low water levels, malfunctioning safety valves, or inadequate cooling.

faults_and_causes.title: Lack of steam
faults_and_causes.description: Insufficient steam pressure can lead to reduced engine performance, misfires, or stalling. Causes can include low water levels, faulty boiler components, or clogged steam passages.

causes.title: Low water levels
causes.description: Faulty boiler components, clogged steam passages, incorrect boiler setting, poor fuel quality, inadequate air flow

causes.title: Clogged condenser
causes.description: Incorrect engine setting, worn or damaged steam cylinders, incorrect lubrication, clogged pipes or tubes

causes.title: Faulty controls or governors
causes.description: Poor maintenance, clogged feedwater system

faults_and_causes.title: Piston and cylinder wear
faults_and_causes.description: As the piston and cylinder move together during operation, they can wear down over time, leading to reduced engine performance and increased fuel consumption.

causes.title: Insufficient Lubrication
causes.description: Lack of proper lubrication can cause piston and cylinder wear in steam engines.

causes.title: Overheating
causes.description: Excessive heat can cause the piston and cylinder to wear down faster than normal.

causes.title: Incorrect Alignment
causes.description: Improper alignment of the piston and cylinder can lead to increased wear.

causes.title: Worn Piston Rings
causes.description: Worn piston rings can cause the piston and cylinder to wear down faster than normal.

causes.title: Cylinder Scrubbing
causes.description: Dirt and debris accumulating on the cylinder walls can cause wear.

causes.title: Incorrect Compression Ratio
causes.description: An incorrect compression ratio can lead to increased wear on the piston and cylinder.

causes.title: Poor Quality Materials
causes.description: Using poor quality materials for the piston and cylinder can lead to premature wear.

causes.title: Incorrect Assembly
causes.description: Improper assembly of the piston and cylinder can lead to increased wear.

causes.title: Foreign Object Damage
causes.description: Damage from foreign objects can cause wear on the piston and cylinder.

causes.title: Over Time Wear
causes.description: Normal wear and tear over time can cause the piston and cylinder to wear down.

faults_and_causes.title: Valve issues
faults_and_causes.description: Faulty valves can cause a range of problems, including poor engine performance, misfires, or overheating. Common issues include stuck valves, damaged valve seats, or worn valve guides.

causes.title: Worn or damaged valve guides
causes.description: Sticky or damaged valve guides can cause the valves to not seat properly, leading to poor engine performance and potential misfires.

causes.title: Stuck valves
causes.description: Valves that do not open or close properly can cause poor engine performance and misfires.

causes.title: Damaged valve seats
causes.description: Damaged valve seats can cause the valves to not seat properly, leading to poor engine performance and potential misfires.

causes.title: Incorrect valve adjustment
causes.description: Improper valve adjustment can lead to poor engine performance and misfires.

causes.title: Low compression
causes.description: Low compression can cause poor engine performance, misfires, and overheating.

causes.title: Overheating
causes.description: Overheating can cause damage to the engine and lead to poor engine performance, misfires, and other issues.

causes.title: Incorrect fuel mixture
causes.description: An incorrect fuel mixture can cause poor engine performance, misfires, and overheating.

causes.title: Clogged air filter
causes.description: A clogged air filter can restrict airflow to the engine, leading to poor engine performance, misfires, and other issues.

causes.title: Worn or damaged piston rings
causes.description: Worn or damaged piston rings can cause the engine to consume more oil and lead to overheating and poor engine performance.

causes.title: Incorrect timing
causes.description: Improper timing can cause poor engine performance, misfires, and other issues.

faults_and_causes.title: Crankshaft and bearings
faults_and_causes.description: The crankshaft and its supporting bearings are subject to heavy loads and high temperatures, which can lead to wear and failure over time. Signs of crankshaft or bearing issues can include rough engine operation, misfires, or grinding noises.

causes.title: Wear and tear
causes.description: Over time, the constant movement of the crankshaft and bearings can lead to wear and tear, which can cause the components to become loose or misaligned. This can result in rough engine operation, misfires, or grinding noises.

causes.title: Insufficient lubrication
causes.description: If the crankshaft and bearings are not properly lubricated, the components can overheat and wear out prematurely. Insufficient lubrication can also lead to corrosion and damage to the engine's components.

causes.title: Overloading
causes.description: Operating the steam engine beyond its recommended load capacity can put excessive stress on the crankshaft and bearings, leading to premature failure.

causes.title: Poor maintenance
causes.description: Failure to properly maintain the steam engine can lead to a range of issues, including crankshaft and bearing failures. This can include neglecting to change the oil, clean the engine, or replace worn components.

causes.title: Incorrect installation
causes.description: If the crankshaft and bearings are not installed correctly, it can lead to misalignment, wear, and premature failure.

causes.title: High temperatures
causes.description: Steam engines can operate at high temperatures, which can cause the crankshaft and bearings to expand and become loose. This can result in rough engine operation, misfires, or grinding noises.

causes.title: Incorrect cooling
causes.description: If the steam engine is not properly cooled, it can lead to overheating of the crankshaft and bearings, which can cause premature failure.

causes.title: Foreign object damage
causes.description: If foreign objects, such as dirt or debris, enter the engine, they can cause damage to the crankshaft and bearings, leading to premature failure.

causes.title: Corrosion
causes.description: Steam engines can be prone to corrosion, particularly if they are not properly maintained. Corrosion can weaken the crankshaft and bearings, leading to premature failure.

causes.title: Manufacturing defects
causes.description: In some cases, crankshaft and bearing failures may be caused by manufacturing defects or design flaws. This is particularly true if multiple engines are experiencing similar issues.

faults_and_causes.title: Connecting rod failure
faults_and_causes.description: The connecting rods connect the piston to the crankshaft and are subject to high stresses and fatigue. Failure can occur due to worn or damaged bearings, improper alignment, or excessive force.

faults_and_causes.title: Gearbox issues
faults_and_causes.description: Steam engines often use gearboxes to step up the speed of the engine before driving a load. Faults in the gearbox can cause reduced performance, noise, or vibration. Common issues include worn gears, damaged bearings, or incorrect lubrication.

causes.title: Worn Gears
causes.description: Gears that are worn down due to excessive use or lack of maintenance can cause issues in the gearbox.

causes.title: Damaged Bearings
causes.description: Bearings that are damaged or worn out can cause the gears to vibrate and make noise, leading to reduced performance and premature wear.

causes.title: Incorrect Lubrication
causes.description: Insufficient or incorrect lubrication can cause the gears to wear down faster and lead to premature failure.

causes.title: Misaligned Gears
causes.description: Gears that are not properly aligned can cause friction and heat buildup, leading to reduced performance and noise.

causes.title: Insufficient Cooling
causes.description: Inadequate cooling can cause the gears to overheat and fail prematurely.

causes.title: Overloading
causes.description: Excessive load on the gearbox can cause the gears to wear down faster and lead to premature failure.

causes.title: Poor Maintenance
causes.description: Failure to properly maintain the gearbox can lead to premature wear and failure.

causes.title: Incorrect Installation
causes.description: Improper installation of the gearbox can cause issues with the alignment and performance of the gears.

causes.title: Foreign Object Damage
causes.description: Damage to the gearbox caused by foreign objects can lead to premature wear and failure.

faults_and_causes.title: Boiler issues
faults_and_causes.description: The boiler is responsible for producing steam for the engine. Faults can include low water levels, scale buildup, or malfunctioning safety valves.

causes.title: Low Water Levels
causes.description: Insufficient water in the boiler can cause the steam pressure to rise, leading to a range of problems, including overheating, drying out of the steam and water mixture, and eventually, failure of the boiler.

causes.title: Scale Buildup
causes.description: Mineral deposits from hard water can accumulate inside the boiler, reducing its efficiency and potentially causing it to fail.

causes.title: Malfunctioning Safety Valves
causes.description: The safety valve is designed to release excess steam pressure when it reaches a certain level. If the valve fails to function properly, it can cause the boiler to overpressure, leading to damage or failure.

causes.title: Poor Water Treatment
causes.description: Using poor quality water or failing to treat the water properly can lead to corrosion and scaling inside the boiler, reducing its efficiency and potentially causing it to fail.

causes.title: Incorrect Boiler Setting
causes.description: Operating the boiler at the wrong pressure or temperature can cause damage to the boiler and its components, leading to Boiler issues.

causes.title: Faulty Feedwater System
causes.description: The feedwater system is responsible for supplying water to the boiler. If the system is faulty, it can cause low water levels, scale buildup, or other Boiler issues.

causes.title: Inadequate Maintenance
causes.description: Failing to properly maintain the boiler and its components can lead to a range of problems, including Boiler issues.

causes.title: Poor Design or Installation
causes.description: A poorly designed or installed boiler can be prone to Boiler issues due to inadequate clearances, improper materials, or other design flaws.

causes.title: Incorrect Fuel Type
causes.description: Using the wrong type of fuel for the boiler can cause problems, such as corrosion or overheating, leading to Boiler issues.

causes.title: Wear and Tear
causes.description: Over time, the boiler's components can wear out, leading to Boiler issues. Regular maintenance and replacement of worn parts can help prevent this.

causes.title: Incorrect Operating Procedures
causes.description: Following incorrect operating procedures can cause Boiler issues, such as overheating or overpressure. Proper training and adherence to established procedures can help prevent this.

causes.title: Environmental Factors
causes.description: Extreme temperatures, humidity, or other environmental factors can affect the boiler's performance and lead to Boiler issues.

faults_and_causes.title: Electrical issues
faults_and_causes.description: Steam engines often use electrical systems to control various functions, such as ignition, fuel injection, and lighting. Faults in these systems can cause a range of problems, including reduced performance, misfires, or complete engine failure.

causes.title: Loose or damaged connections
causes.description: Faulty connections can cause electrical issues in steam engines.

causes.title: Faulty wiring or harnesses
causes.description: Defective wiring or harnesses can lead to electrical problems in steam engines.

causes.title: Incorrect voltage or frequency
causes.description: Operating the engine at the wrong voltage or frequency can cause electrical issues.

causes.title: Moisture or condensation
causes.description: Water or humidity in the engine can cause short circuits and other electrical problems.

causes.title: Overloading or overheating
causes.description: Running the engine at too high a load or temperature can cause electrical issues.

causes.title: Poor maintenance
causes.description: Failure to properly maintain the engine can lead to electrical problems.

causes.title: Incorrect component installation
causes.description: Improper installation of components can cause electrical issues in steam engines.

causes.title: EMI/RFI interference
causes.description: Electromagnetic interference (EMI) or radio-frequency interference (RFI) can affect the proper functioning of steam engine electrical systems.

causes.title: Inadequate grounding
causes.description: Poor grounding can cause electrical issues in steam engines.

causes.title: Obsolescence
causes.description: Outdated or obsolete components can cause electrical issues in steam engines.
